name: Word problems with two step inequalities

skills.name: Form inequalities from situations described in words
Form and solve inequalities from situations described in words

explanations.A: This inequality shows a cost of $4 per ride and $3.50 admission ticket. If 'ùë•' is the number of rides, how should we write this instead?
explanations.B: I think you've got your inequalities mixed up. > is 'greater than'. Can he spend greater than 60 if he only has $60?
explanations.C: It's $4 admission and $3.50 per ride (ùë•). We can represent this cost as 4 + 3.50ùë•. He has $60, so the amount he spends must be less than or equal to 60. Therefore, 4 + 3.50ùë• ‚â§ 60.
explanations.D: Close, but if he has $60 to spend, he could also spend exactly 60. How could we show this in our inequality sign?

explanations.A: Close, but if he has $40 to spend, he could also spend exactly 40. How could we show this in our inequality sign?
explanations.B: It's $2.50 admission and $3 per ride (ùë•). We can represent this cost as 2.50 + 3ùë•. He has $40, so the amount he spends must be less than or equal to 40. Therefore, 2.50 + 3ùë• ‚â§ 40.
explanations.C: This inequality shows a cost of $2.50 per ride and $3 admission ticket. If 'ùë•' is the number of rides, how should we write this instead?
explanations.D: I think you've got your inequalities mixed up. > is 'greater than'. Can he spend greater than 40 if he only has $40?

explanations.A: 50 - 6 = 44, so he has $44 to spend on rides. $44 divided by $2.50 equals 17.6. He hasn't quite got enough to go on 18 rides, so the maximum would be 17.
explanations.B: I think you've used $2.50 as the admission fee and then $6 per ride which is mixed up from what we are given in the question.
explanations.C: I think you've rounded up from 17.6, however if he only has enough money for 17.6 rides, will he be able to pay for 18 of them?
explanations.D: I think you've added $6 and $2.50 together and then divided by this, but the $6 admission is only a one-off payment so only needs to be taken away once.

explanations.A: I think you've used $4 as the admission fee and then $5.50 per ride which is mixed up from what we are given in the question.
explanations.B: I think you've added $5.50 and $4 together and then divided by this, but the $5.50 admission is only a one-off payment so only needs to be taken away once.
explanations.C: 60 - 5.50 = 54.50, so he has $54.50 to spend on rides. $54.50 divided by $4 equals 13.6. He hasn't quite got enough to go on 14 rides, so the maximum would be 13.
explanations.D: I think you've rounded up from 13.6, however if he only has enough money for 13.6 rides, will he be able to pay for 14 of them?

explanations.A: Very close, but because the question says 'at most', this could also include 65 pounds. How could we show that in our inequality symbol?
explanations.B: I think you've got your inequalities mixed up. > is 'greater than' but we are told that the dog has to weigh 65 or less.
explanations.C: Not quite, I think you've used the dog's current weight for the inequality rather than the weight that the vet has said the dog should be.
explanations.D: The dog's weight needs to be below or equal to 65, meaning the symbol ‚â§ would be appropriate for the inequality. We are starting at 98, then losing 3 pounds per week (ùë•), so the inequality would be 98 - 3ùë• ‚â§ 65

explanations.A: The dogs weight needs to be less than or equal to 58, meaning this symbol ‚â§ would be appropriate for the inequality. We are starting at 72, then losing 2 pounds per week (ùë•), so the inequality would be 72 - 2ùë• ‚â§ 58
explanations.B: Not quite, I think you've used the dog's current weight for the inequality rather than the weight that the vet has said the dog should be.
explanations.C: Very close, but because the question says 'at most', this could also include 58 pounds. How could we show that in our inequality symbol?
explanations.D: I think you've got your inequalities mixed up. > is 'greater than' but we are told that the dog has to weigh 58 or less.

explanations.A: Close, but remember that when we divide an inequality by a negative, we have to switch the sign!
explanations.B: 65 - 98 = -33, giving us -3x ‚â§ -33. When we divide by -3, we switch the inequality symbol, so we would have x ‚â• 11.
explanations.C: I think your inequality might be back to front. We are starting at 98 and then subtracting 3 pounds per week (ùë•).
explanations.D: Close, but it could also include 11 weeks! How can we show that on our inequality symbol?

explanations.A: I think your inequality might be back to front. We are starting at 72 and then subtracting 2 pounds per week (ùë•).
explanations.B: Close, but remember that when we divide an inequality by a negative, we have to switch the sign!
explanations.C: Close, but it could also include 7 weeks! How can we show that on our inequality symbol?
explanations.D: 58 - 72 = -14, giving us -2ùë• ‚â§ -14. When we divide by -2, we switch the inequality symbol, so we would have ùë• ‚â• 7.

explanations.A: We only have to switch the symbol when dividing by a negative. It's fine to leave it as it is if the inequality contains negatives as long as we don't divide by one!
explanations.B: When solving an inequality, we want to do things in the opposite order. So if the inequality is 2ùë• + 6, we would subtract the 6 first!
explanations.C: -88 subtract 6 is -94. If we divide by 2, we get -47. As the question says 'no more than', it can be equal to or less than, which is the ‚â§ symbol.
explanations.D: When solving an inequality, we want to do things in the opposite order. So if the inequality is 2ùë• + 6, we would subtract the 6 first!

explanations.A: When solving an inequality, we want to do things in the opposite order. So if the inequality is 2ùë• + 10, we would subtract the 10 first!
explanations.B: -32 subtract 10 is -42. If we divide by 2, we get -21. As the question says 'no more than', it can be equal to or less than, which is the ‚â§ symbol.
explanations.C: We only have to switch the symbol when dividing by a negative. It's fine to leave it as it is if the inequality contains negatives as long as we don't divide by one!
explanations.D: When solving an inequality, we want to do things in the opposite order. So if the inequality is 2ùë• + 10, we would subtract the 10 first!
